t: The*p words of the Preacher, the son of David, king in Jerusalem.
Vanity*p of vanities, saith the Preacher, vanity of vanities; all is vanity.
What*p profit hath a man of all his labour which he taketh under the sun?
One*p generation passeth away, and another generation cometh: but the earth abideth for ever.
The*p sun also ariseth, and the sun goeth down, and hasteth to his place where he arose.
The*p wind goeth toward the south, and turneth about unto the north; it whirleth about continually, and the wind returneth again according to his circuits.
All*p the rivers run into the sea; yet the sea is not full; unto the place from whence the rivers come, thither they return again.
All*p things are full of labour; man cannot utter it: the eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the ear filled with hearing.
The*p thing that hath been, it is that which shall be; and that which is done is that which shall be done: and there is no new thing under the sun.
Is*p there any thing whereof it may be said, See, this is new? it hath been already of old time, which was before us.
There*p is no remembrance of former things; neither shall there be any remembrance of things that are to come with those that shall come after.
I*p the Preacher was king over Israel in Jerusalem.
And*p I gave my heart to seek and search out by wisdom concerning all things that are done under heaven: this sore travail hath God given to the sons of man to be exercised therewith.
I*p have seen all the works that are done under the sun; and, behold, all is vanity and vexation of spirit.
That*p which is crooked cannot be made straight: and that which is wanting cannot be numbered.

I*p communed with mine own heart, saying, Lo, I am come to great estate, and have gotten more wisdom than all they that have been before me in Jerusalem: yea, my heart had great experience of wisdom and knowledge.
And*p I gave my heart to know wisdom, and to know madness and folly: I perceived that this also is vexation of spirit.
For*p in much wisdom is much grief: and he that increaseth knowledge increaseth sorrow.
